data.title: Famous People Who Died in 1971
data.meta_description: Famous deaths in 1971. Learn about 365 historical figures, notable people and celebrities who died in 1971 like Nikita Khrushchev, Jim Morrison and Louis Armstrong.
data.text:
Deaths 1 - 200 of 365

Amphilochius of Pochayiv [Yakov Varnavovich Golovatyuk], Ukrainian Orthodox Christian saint, dies at 76

Lloyd Hall, African-American chemist and pioneer in food chemistry (science of food preservation), dies at 76

Jan 2 Richard Maxwell (Dick) Haldane, South African trade unionist, dies at 62

Jan 2 Willard Maas, American educator and experimental filmmaker, dies at 64

Arthur Ford, American clairaudient (b. 1896)

Columbus O'Donnell Iselin, American oceanographer, dies at 66

Jan 5 Douglas Shearer, Canadian film engineer (b. 1899)

Madame Spivy [Bertha Levine], American actress (All Fall Down) and nightclub owner, dies of cancer at 64

Jan 7 Richard "Dick" Kollmar, American actor (Broadway Spotlight, Guess What), dies from complications from a blood clotting disorder at 60

Adriano Lualdi, Italian composer (Il diavolo nel campanile), and conductor, dies at 85

Elmer Flick, American Baseball HOF outfielder (AL batting champion 1905; NL RBI leader 1900; 2 × AL stolen base leader; Philadelphia Phillies, Cleveland Bronchos/Naps), dies at 94

Jan 9 Giannis Christou, Greek composer (b. 1926)

(Gabrielle) "Coco" Chanel, French fashion designer (Chanel), dies at 87

Irene Rice Pereira, American abstract artist, dies aged 68

Bernard "Heinz" Lammerding, German SS-gen/contractor (Tulle), dies at 65

Jan 13 Henri Tomasi, French conductor, classical and film music composer (Requiem for Peace; The Silence of the Sea), dies at 69

Jan 13 Robert Still, English composer, dies at 60

Ethel Glenn Hier, American composer, dies at 82

John Dall, actor (Corn is Green, Rope), dies of a heart attack at 50

Kermit Maynard, American cowboy actor (Valley of Terror, Saturday Roundup), dies at 73

Jan 16 Philippe Thys, Belgian cyclist (three times winner of Tour de France), dies at 81

Catherine Calvert, American actress (Fires of Faith), dies of stroke at 80

Harry Shields, American musician (b. 1899)

Antonio Bacci, Italian cardinal, dies at 85

Jan 20 Broncho Billy Anderson [Maxwell Aronson], American silent and sound screen actor, the 1st cowboy in a movie (The Great Train Robbery; A Lucky Dog), and studio executive, dies at 90 [1]

Richard B Russell, (Sen-D-Ga), dies at 73

Fritz Feigl, Austria-born chemist (b. 1871)

Bill W. [William Wilson], American co-founder of Alcoholics Anonymous (b. 1895)

Jacobo Árbenz

President of Guatemala (1951-54); overthrown by CIA, dies at 57

Donald Winnicott, British psychoanalyst (b. 1896)

Viktor Maksimovich Zhirmunsky, Russian literary historian and linguist, dies at 79

Jim Christy, South African cricket batsman (10 Tests; top score 103 1932; Transvaal, Queensland), dies at 66

Jay C. Flippen, American actor (Jet Pilot, The Killing, Thunder Bay), dies at 71

Mátyás Rákosi, Hungarian party leader and Prime Minister (1952-53), dies at 78

Morgan Lee "Dock" Boggs, American folk and blues singer and banjo player, dies on his 73rd birthday

Whitney Young Jr, National Urban League director, drowns in Nigeria

George Shelton, American actor (It Pays to be Ignorant), dies at 86

James Cash Penney

American department store founder (J C Penney), dies at 95

Marian Koval, Soviet Russian composer, dies at 63

Teddy Hart, American actor (After the Thin Man, 3 Men on a Horse), dies at 73

Alexander Tsfasman, Soviet Russian jazz pianist, composer, and arranger, dies at 64

Adolph Weiss, American bassoonist and composer, dies at 79

Feb 21 Robert Manry, American copy editor of the Cleveland newspaper editor who sailed the Atlantic (Tinkerbelle), dies of a heart attack at 52

Barry Macollum, actor (On the Waterfront), dies at 81

Feb 22 Matt McHugh, American actor (Taxi, Freaks, Barbary Coast, Innocent Affair), dies at 77

Feb 22 Rudolf Mauersberger, German choral conductor and composer (Dresdner Requiem), dies at 82

King Lockwood, dies of stroke at 73

Theodor Svedberg, Swedish chemist, worked with colloids (Nobel 1926), dies at 86

Edward van der Merwe, South African cricket wicket-keeper (2 Tests in 30's), dies at 67

Feb 26 Fernandel [Fernand Contandin], French actor (The Little World of Don Camillo), dies of lung cancer at 67

Feb 26 Josef Berg, Czech composer, and librettist dies at 43

Feb 26 Tullio Carminati, Austrian actor (War and Peace; Roman Holiday), dies at 76

Charles W Engelhard, US silver multi-millionaire, dies at 54

Winnie Lightner [Winifred Reeves], American vaudeville stage and screen actress, and singer (Gold Diggers of Broadway; Gold Dust Gertie; Sit Tight), dies at 71

Raymond Herreman, Belgian poet, journalist and writer (Jericho's Rose), dies at 74

Mar 6 Thurston Dart, English harpsichordist and conductor, dies at 49

Harold McNair, British-Jamaican calypso and jazz saxophonist and flautist, dies of lung cancer at 39

Mar 7 Stevie Smith [Florence Margaret Smith], English poet and novelist ("A Good Time Was Had By All"; "Not Waving but Drowning") whose life was turned into the play and film "Stevie", dies of a brain tumour at 68

Harold Lloyd, American silent and sound film actor, comedian, and director (Why Worry?; The Freshman; Safety Last!; The Sin of Harold Diddlebock), dies of cancer at 77

Jean-Pierre Guézec, French composer (Colorful Architectures), dies of a heart attack at 36

Mabel Wheeler Daniels, American composer (Deep Forest, The Desolate City), dies at 92

Philo Farnsworth, American inventor (created electronic television, video camera tube), dies of pneumonia at 64

Mar 11 Whitney Young Jr, American leader (National Urban League 1961-71), dies at 49

David Burns, American actor (The Music Man; Hello Dolly!), dies of a heart attack at 68

Mar 12 Roy Glenn, American radio and screen character actor (Rocky Jordan; The Jack Benny Show; Amos 'n' Andy; Guess Who's Coming to Dinner), dies of a heart attack at 56

Piero Coppola, Italian conductor, artistic director (La Voix de son Maître (The Gramophone Company - France), 1923-34). pianist, and composer, dies at 82

Mar 13 Rockwell Kent, American artist, painter and illustrator (Canterbury Tales), dies at 88

Jean-Pierre Monseré, Belgian cyclist (b. 1948)

(Phyllis) "Bebe" Daniels, American silent film, radio, and screen actress (Silver Dollar; My Past), dies at 70

Mar 16 Chuck Fleetwood-Smith, Australian cricket wrist-spin bowler (10 Tests), dies from cancer at 62

Thomas E. Dewey

Governor of NY and Republican presidential candidate (1944, 1948), dies of a heart attack at 68

Ernst Bachmeister, German writer, dies at 96

George Wood, England cricket wicket-keeper (3 Tests, 6 dismissals; Cambridge University CC, Kent CCC), dies at 77

Jan Greshoff, Dutch poet/author/journalist (Last Things), dies at 82

Mar 19 Mary Dorna [Mary Jeanette Tenkink-Stoppelman], Dutch author, dies at 79

Nan Wynn [Masha Vatz], American radio and big-band singer (Rudy Vallée; Teddy Wilson), actress (Pardon My Sarong), and singing voice for Rita Hayworth, dies of cancer at 55 [1]

Martin Bodmer, Swiss Bibliophile and scholar (Bodmer Papyri), dies at 71

Armin Loos, German-born American composer, dies at 67

Mar 23 Simon Vestdijk, Dutch writer and poet (Brass Garden), dies at 72

Felix Wolfes, German-American conductor, educator (New England Conservatory, 1948-68), and composer, dies at 78

Dhirendranath Datta, Bangladeshi politician, tortured to death at 84

Selmer Jackson, American actor (The Grapes of Wrath, Life & Legend of Wyatt Earp), dies at 82

Alfred Desenclos, French composer, mostly of liturgical works (Messe de Requiem), and teacher, dies at 59

Mar 31 Liselotte Liselot Beekmeyer, Dutch actress (Child Crying), dies at 31

Baby Face Willette [Roosevelt Willet], American hard bop and soul-jazz Hammond organ player, dies of bronchial pneumonia at 37

Apr 1 Kathleen Lonsdale, Irish-born British pacifist and crystallographer (one of 1st two women elected to Royal Society), dies of cancer at 68

Willy Lages, German chief of Sicherheitsdienst in Amsterdam (deported 70,000 Dutch Jews to death camps), dies at 70

Joseph Valachi, American gangster, dies at 66

Apr 3 Manfred Bonnington Lee [Ellery Queen], American detective writer, dies at 65

Earl "Jock" Caruthers American jazz saxophonist (Jimmie Lunceford Orchestra, 1932-47), dies at 60

Igor Stravinsky

Russian composer (Le Sacre du Printemps - The Rite of Spring; The Firebird), dies of pneumonia at 88

Charles F Pahud de Mortanges, (Olympic gold 1928, 32), dies at 74

Apr 7 Charles Pahud de Mortanges, Dutch equestrian (Olympic gold individual 3 day event 1928, 32; team 3 day event 1924, 28), dies at 74

Will Harridge, American Baseball HOF executive (President American League 1931-59), dies at 87

Ed Lafitte, American baseball pitcher (no-hitter 1914 Brooklyn Tip-Tops), dies at 85

Apr 12 Wynton Kelly, American jazz pianist (Dizzy Gillespie; Miles Davis), dies of epileptic seizure at 39

Juhan Smuul, Estonian author, dies at 49

Apr 13 Michel Brière, Canadian NHL ice hockey player, 1969-70 (Pittsburgh Penquins), dies from injuries sustained in a car crash, after 11 months in a coma, at 21

Armand Spitz, developer of small educational planetarium, dies

Dan Reeves, American NFL team owner (Cleveland, LA Rams), dies at 58

Carmen Lombardo, Canadian musician, dies at 67

Apr 17 Roberto Lupi, Italian composer, dies at 62

Masao Ohki, Japanese composer (Idea of the Night; Hiroshima Symphony), dies of cancer at 69

Russ Hodges, American sportscaster (NY Mets, SF Giants; Wednesday Night Fights), dies at 60

Cecil Parker, British actor (The Lady Vanishes, Indiscreet, Tale of 2 Cities), dies at 73

Edmund Lowe, American actor (Black Sheep, Good Sam, Dillinger, Hot Pepper), dies at 81

François Duvalier

Dictator and President of Haiti (1957-71), dies of heart disease and diabetes at 64

William V. S. Tubman, Liberian politician (President of Liberia 1944-71), dies at 76

Lennie Hayton, American pianist, composer, conductor and arranger (Paul Whiteman; Bing Crosby; MGM), dies at of heart attack at 63

Max Drischner, German organist, harpsichordist, kantor, and composer, dies at 80

Elmo Roper, pollster (Roper Poll), dies at 70

Edith Day, American actress (A Romance of the Air), dies at 75

May 1 Glenda Farrell, American actress (Golddiggers of 1935: Grand Slam; Exposed), dies of lung cancer at 66

Donald Dexter Van Slyke, American chemist (Micromanometric analysis), dies at 88

May 4 Joseph Csaky, Hungarian-French sculptor (Cubism), dies at 83

May 4 Louis de Bree [Louis Davids], actor (De man zonder hart, The Cross-Patch, Bluejackets), dies at 87

May 4 Seamus Elliott, Irish road bicycle racer (first English speaker to win stages in all the Grand Tours), dies at 36

Alice Tissot, French actress (Italian Straw Hat), dies of cancer at 81

May 5 Harry Moorman, Dutch vice-admiral (KVP), dies at 71

May 5 Petro Scaglione, Italian procureur-general, killed by Mafia

May 5 Violet Jessop, Titanic survivor (b. 1887)

Helene Weigel, Austrian/German actress (Metropolis), dies at 70

Willem Banning, Dutch theologist and sociologist (Karl Marx), dies at 83

Mihail Jora, Romanian composer, dies at 79

May 10 Shukichi Mitsukuri, Japanese composer (10 Haikai de Basho), dies at 75

Alan Mara Bateman, Canadian geologist (Yale professor), dies at 82

Heinie Manush, American Baseball HOF left fielder (MLB All-Star 1934 Washington Sens; AL batting champion 1926 Detroit Tigers), dies from throat cancer at 69

May 12 Johnny Taylor, Australian cricket batsman (20 Tests; 1 x 100, 8 x 50) and rugby union fly-half (2 caps), dies at 75

May 12 Tor Johnson [Tore Johansson], Swedish wrestler and actor (Bride of the Monster), dies at 67

Valerian Mikhaylovich Bogdanov-Berezovsky, Russian composer, dies 67

Donald F. Duncan Sr., American entrepreneur (Duncan Toys Company), dies at 78

May 15 Goose Goslin, American Baseball HOF left fielder (World Series 1924 Washington Sens, 1935 Detroit Tigers; AL batting champion 1928; MLB All Star 1936), dies at 70

May 15 Sir Tyrone Guthrie, British actor, producer, writer and director, dies at 70

Barney Stanley, Canadian Hockey Hall of Fame forward (Stanley Cup 1915, Vancouver Millionaires; coach Chicago Black Hawks 1927-28), dies at 77

Bernard Wagenaar, Dutch-American composer (3 Songs for Chinese), dies at 76

Ogden Nash

American humorous poet (I'm a Stranger Here Myself, Masquerade Party), dies at 68 [1]

Martín Dihigo, Cuban Baseball HOF two-way player (2 × Negro League All-Star New York Cubans; 4 × Cuban League MVP), dies at 65

May 20 Waldo Williams, Welsh poet (b. 1904)

Dennis King, English actor (Devil's Brother), dies of heart ailment at 73

Frank Ottersen, Norwegian jazz violinist and saxophonist (Ding, Dong, Dang), dies at 50

Charles P. Cabell, American military and intelligence officer (US Air Force general; Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, 1953–1962), dies of a heart attack at 67

May 25 Jo Etha Collier, young African American woman killed by 3 whites in Drew, Mississippi

May 25 Mark Brunswick, American composer, dies at 69

May 25 Terence De Marney, British actor (Lorna Doone, Doctor Who, The Immortal Gentleman), dies after accidentally falling under a subway at 63

John Longden, British actor (Man From Interpol), dies at 70

Chips Rafferty [John William Pilbean Goffage], Australian actor (Wake in Fright, Desert Rats), dies from a heart attack at 62

May 27 Jack Doscher, American baseball pitcher (1st son of a major leaguer to play MLB), dies at 90

Audie Murphy, American soldier who was among the most decorated in WW II with 33 medals and actor (To Hell and Back, Whispering Smiths), killed in a plane crash at 46

May 28 Jean Vilar, French stage and film actor and director (Théâtre National Populaire), dies at 59

Max Trapp, German composer, dies at 83

Marcel Dupré, French organist and composer, dies at 85

May 30 Rodd Redwing, American actor (Buffalo Bill In Tomahawk Territory; Son Of Geronimo), and stunt coach, dies of a heart attack at 66

Bert Ironmonger, Australian cricket spin bowler (14 Tests; 74 wickets @ 17.97; Queensland, Victoria), dies at 89

May 31 Massimo Campigli, Italian painter and illustrator, dies at 75

Reinhold Niebuhr

American theologian (Nature & Destiny of Man), dies at 78

Charles de Keukeleire, Belgian director (Evil Eye), dies at 66

Heinz Hopf, German mathematician, dies at 76

Georg Lukács, Hungarian philosopher and literary critic, dies at 86

Arnold Elston, American composer, and educator, dies at 63

Harold Lloyd Jr, American actor (Frankenstein's Daughter), cabaret singer, and son of famous silent film actor Harold Lloyd, Sr., dies of a complications from a stroke at 40

Michael Rennie, British actor (The Day the Earth Stood Still), dies at 61

Jun 10 Virginia True Boardman, American actress of the silent era (A Blind Bargain; The Lady Lies), dies of a heart attack at 82

Carlos P. Garcia, 8th President of the Philippines (1957-61), dies at 74

Wendell Meredith Stanley, American chemist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1904)

Garfield Wood, American inventor, motorboat builder and racer (world water speed record x 5; first to travel over 100 mph on water), dies at 90

Jun 16 John Reith, Scottish broadcast executive (General Manager of the BBC), dies at 81

C Christopher Morris, cricketer (brilliant batsman for Philadelphia), dies

Paul Karrer, Swiss organic chemist (Nobel 1937), dies at 82

Jun 18 Thomas Gomez, American actor (Force of Evil, Key Largo, Kim, Sellout), dies after a car accident at 65

George Blagoi, entertainer, dies

Jun 23 Walter Schulthess, Swiss composer, dies at 76

John Dunning, cricketer (4 Tests for NZ 1933-37), dies

Charles Vildrac, French author, poet and playwright (La Brouille, Michel Auclair, Notes sur la technique poétique), dies at 88

Jun 25 John Boyd Orr, Scottish physician (Nobel Peace Prize 1949 - Father of the Food and Agriculture Organization), dies at 90 [1]

Guillermo Uribe Holguin, composer, dies at 91

Jun 26 Inia Te Wiata, opera singer, dies

Jun 26 Juan Manen, composer, dies at 88

Franz Stangl, Austrian commandant of concentration camps (b. 1908)

Jun 28 Henri Puvrez, Belgian sculptor (Serenity), dies at 78

Jun 28 Joseph Colombo, mobster, shot dead at 48

Néstor Mesta Cháyres, Mexican lyric tenor, dies of a heart attack ay 63

Georgy Dobrovolsky, Soviet cosmonaut (Soyuz 11), dies in outer space aboard Soyuz 11 at 43

Jun 30 Herbert Biberman, Jewish American screenwriter and film director (b. 1900)

Jun 30 Viktor Patsayev, Soviet cosmonaut (Soyuz 11-landing accident), dies in outer space aboard Soyuz 11 at 38

Jun 30 Vladislav Volkov, Soviet-Russian cosmonaut (Soyuz 7, 11), dies in outer space aboard Soyuz 11 at 35

(William) Lawrence Bragg, English physicist, Nobel Prize for Physics, 1915 - crystalline structure analysis), dies at 81 [1]

Jul 1 Learie Constantine, West Indian cricket all-rounder, lawyer and politician (UK's first black peer), dies of a heart attack at 69 [1]

Edward Ballantine, American composer and music professor, dies at 84

Jim Morrison

American singer-songwriter (The Doors) and poet, dies of heart failure allegedly caused be an accidental heroin overdose at 27

Renie Riano, British-American vaudeville and screen actress (Jiggs and Maggie films; The Family Jewels), dies after long illness at 71

August Derleth, American writer (Judge Peck Mysteries) and editor, dies of a heart attack at 62

Jul 4 Don McPherson, American R&B singer (The Main Ingredient - "Everybody Plays the Fool"), dies of leukemia at 29

Jul 4 Joe Cox, South African cricket fast medium bowler (3 Tests; Natal), dies at 85

Jul 4 Maurice Bowra, British classics scholar (Greek experience), dies at 73

Jul 4 Thomas C. Hart, U.S. admiral and commander (Pacific Fleet), dies at 94

Horst Lange, German writer (The Long Lament), dies at 66

Louis Armstrong

American jazz trumpeter and singer (Hello Dolly; What A Wonderful World), dies of a heart attack at 69

Jul 6 Thomas C Heart, US admiral/commander (Asiatic fleet), dies

Claude Gauvreau, Canadian writer (b. 1925)

Jul 7 Ub Iwerks, American artist, director, and cartoonist (b1901)
